Notification
Sending something to the user.

p.p: Telegram is a popular messenger with a rich support of bot actions (Payments, Games, Callbacks). As the Flow is too heavy to run a realtime bot, the only useful purpose is notifications sending. You can send a notifications either to a chat (one-to-one) with user, or to a channel (one-to-many).

div.p: At first, go to a @BotFather and create your bot. Here you will get your API token.
div.h3: Sending message to a personal chat
div.p: It's pretty hard to get your personal chat_id unless you know the following:

ul.li: Find your bot in the Telegram search.
Find a {message}->{chat}->{id} value in the JSON.
Ensure this is a message from you.
Use this value as a receiver.
Create a channel (if you're not already owning one).
Open Channel settings and get the channel link. It should be something like ' https://t.me/your_channel_id '
Use the part after t.me/ with an '@' prepended as a receiver (@your_channel_id in this case).

div.div:
Plugin Configurations
Plugin configurations are sets of parameters that apply across some or all of the plugin procedures. They reduce repetition of common values, create predefined parameter sets for end users, and securely store credentials where needed. Each configuration is given a unique name that is entered in designated parameters on procedures that use them.
Creating Plugin Configurations
To create plugin configurations in ElectricFlow, do these steps:
Go to Administration > Plugins to open the Plugin Manager.
Find the @PLUGIN_NAME@ row.
Click Configure to open the Configurations page.
Click Create Configuration as per the description of parameters below.
Configuration Parameters
Parameter Description
Configuration Name The name for the created configuration
Description Description for the configuration
Telegram Bot API The URL to request the updates
API Token Bot API token (request one from @BotFather)
Check Connection?
Debug Level
